children.content: is a “rule” for transforming inputs (usually numbers) into outputs (usually numbers as well). One can think of a function as a box with an “input tube” and an “output tube”:
An input goes in via the input tube, is processed according to the function's rule, and the result comes out the other side. (Metaphorically speaking.)

children.content: As it turns out, the term “graph” just means “set of points in the plane”. So a
(as described above) is just one particular kind of “graph” among other things that are also called “graphs”, but that are not function graphs.

children.content: ] is a function graph if and only if every
-value (a.k.a., input) corresponds to at most one
-value (a.k.a., output). In other words, every vertical line should intersect the graph at most once.
is a function graph (or locally at least, from what we can see), because every vertical line intersects the graph at most once, but this graph...
...is not the graph of any function, because some vertical lines intersect the graph more than once.

from the graph. A filled circle, by opposition, means that the point is included!)
